title: Job Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who answered in Job Chapter 20?
questions.correctAnswer: Zophar the Naamathite
questions.explanation: Job 20:1 states that Zophar the Naamathite answered.

questions.question: According to Job 20:5, how long is the triumphing of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Short
questions.explanation: Job 20:5 says that the triumphing of the wicked is short.

questions.question: What will happen to the wicked according to Job 20:7?
options: He shall perish forever like his own dung
questions.correctAnswer: He shall perish forever like his own dung
questions.explanation: Job 20:7 states that the wicked shall perish forever like his own dung.

questions.question: According to Job 20:8, the wicked shall fly away as what?
questions.correctAnswer: A dream
questions.explanation: Job 20:8 says the wicked shall fly away as a dream.

questions.question: In Job 20:12, what is said about wickedness in the mouth of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: It is sweet
questions.explanation: Job 20:12 states that wickedness is sweet in his mouth.

questions.question: What shall happen to the riches swallowed by the wicked, according to Job 20:15?
options: He shall vomit them up again
questions.correctAnswer: He shall vomit them up again
questions.explanation: Job 20:15 says the wicked hath swallowed down riches, and he shall vomit them up again.

questions.question: According to Job 20:16, what shall the wicked suck that will slay him?
questions.correctAnswer: The poison of asps
questions.explanation: Job 20:16 mentions he shall suck the poison of asps and the viper's tongue shall slay him.

questions.question: What will the wicked not see according to Job 20:17?
options: The rivers, floods, brooks of honey and butter
questions.correctAnswer: The rivers, floods, brooks of honey and butter
questions.explanation: Job 20:17 says he shall not see the rivers, floods, brooks of honey and butter.

questions.question: True or False: Job 20:19 says the wicked oppressed and forsook the poor.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 20:19 states that the wicked hath oppressed and forsaken the poor.

questions.question: What shall happen to the wicked when he is about to fill his belly as per Job 20:23?
options: God shall cast the fury of his wrath upon him
questions.correctAnswer: God shall cast the fury of his wrath upon him
questions.explanation: Job 20:23 states that when he is about to fill his belly, God shall cast the fury of his wrath upon him.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "The heaven shall reveal his ______; and the earth shall rise up against him."
questions.correctAnswer: iniquity
questions.explanation: Job 20:27 states 'The heaven shall reveal his iniquity; and the earth shall rise up against him.'

questions.question: According to Job 20:28, what shall happen to the increase of the wicked man's house?
questions.correctAnswer: It shall depart
questions.explanation: Job 20:28 says the increase of his house shall depart.

questions.question: True or False: Job 20:20 says the wicked shall feel quietness in his belly.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 20:20 says surely he shall not feel quietness in his belly.

questions.question: What is the heritage appointed unto the wicked man by God according to Job 20:29?
options: This is the portion of a wicked man from God
questions.correctAnswer: This is the portion of a wicked man from God
questions.explanation: Job 20:29 states 'This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the heritage appointed unto him by God.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 20:9, the wicked's place shall no more behold him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 20:9 says the wicked's place shall no more behold him.

medium.title: Job Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Job 20, what biblical truth would you share about the fate of the wicked?
options: The triumph of the wicked is short and their joy fleeting
The wicked will be blessed with lasting peace
The wicked will be remembered and honored forever
questions.correctAnswer: The triumph of the wicked is short and their joy fleeting
questions.explanation: Job 20:5 teaches that 'the triumphing of the wicked is short, and the joy of the hypocrite but for a moment.' Verses 7-9 further explain that the wicked will perish and be forgotten, emphasizing the transient nature of their success.

questions.question: How does Job 20 instruct believers about the consequences of wickedness in relation to honesty and integrity at work?
options: Wickedness leads to loss and restitution of ill-gotten gains
Integrity is unimportant as long as one succeeds
Wickedness brings lasting wealth and honor
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness leads to loss and restitution of ill-gotten gains
questions.explanation: Job 20:15-18 explains how the wicked swallow riches but will vomit them, and that what they labored for will be restored to others. This teaches that dishonest gain will not bring lasting blessing.

questions.question: What biblical virtue is taught in Job 20 regarding the treatment of the poor?
options: Oppressing the poor leads to loss and unrest
Taking from the poor brings lasting success
The poor should be avoided for personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: Oppressing the poor leads to loss and unrest
questions.explanation: Job 20:19-20 states that because the wicked have oppressed and forsaken the poor, they will not find quietness or fulfillment. This underscores the importance of generosity and justice towards the needy.

questions.question: How does Job 20 describe the internal consequences of sin and hidden wickedness?
options: Wickedness, though sweet at first, turns bitter within
Sin brings internal peace and joy
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness, though sweet at first, turns bitter within
questions.explanation: Job 20:12-14 illustrates that although wickedness may seem sweet initially, it turns into gall and poison inside, highlighting the spiritual and psychological harm of sin.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment during difficult times. What does Job 20 teach about the sufficiency and unrest of the wicked?
options: In fullness, the wicked will be in straits and unrest
The wicked will always be content and satisfied
Sufficiency guarantees peace for the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: In fullness, the wicked will be in straits and unrest
questions.explanation: Job 20:22 shows that even in abundance, the wicked will experience distress and troubles, teaching that true peace does not come from wealth or worldly sufficiency.

questions.question: According to Job 20, what happens when the wicked try to enjoy their ill-gotten gains?
options: God’s wrath will come upon them while they are eating
They will enjoy peace and prosperity
They will be praised by others
questions.correctAnswer: God’s wrath will come upon them while they are eating
questions.explanation: Job 20:23 emphasizes that when the wicked try to fill their belly with their riches, God will cast His wrath upon them, showing that enjoying sinful gain leads to divine judgment.

questions.question: What does Job 20 teach about the ultimate destiny of the wicked in relation to their legacy and possessions?
options: Their goods and increase will depart on the day of wrath
Their possessions will be inherited by their children
Their legacy will be honored forever
Their wealth will multiply and be secure
questions.correctAnswer: Their goods and increase will depart on the day of wrath
questions.explanation: Job 20:28 states that the increase of the wicked’s house shall depart and their goods shall flow away during God's wrath, teaching that material wealth is temporary for the wicked.

questions.question: How does Job 20 urge believers to view the heritage and portion of the wicked from God’s perspective?
options: The wicked’s portion is appointed by God and leads to destruction
The wicked have no portion from God
God blesses the wicked with everlasting life
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked’s portion is appointed by God and leads to destruction
questions.explanation: Job 20:29 clearly states that the portion of the wicked is from God and is appointed to lead to their downfall, teaching that God’s justice prevails.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 20, the wicked will have lasting peace and their place will be remembered forever.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 20:7-9 explains that the wicked will perish and not be found again; their place will no longer behold them, indicating no lasting peace or remembrance.

questions.question: True or False: Job 20 teaches that even though the wicked may try to hide their sin, it ultimately harms them deeply.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 20:12-14 describes how wickedness, though initially sweet and hidden, turns into poison within, teaching that hidden sin brings internal harm.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Job 20, a wicked man’s bones are full of the sin of his ________, which shall lie down with him in the dust.
questions.correctAnswer: youth
questions.explanation: Job 20:11 states that the wicked man’s bones are full of the sin of his youth, indicating that early sins accompany him to death.

questions.question: How does Job 20 instruct believers about humility and contentment by contrasting the fate of the wicked?
options: The wicked’s exaltation is temporary and leads to ruin
Exaltation leads to lasting peace regardless of conduct
Humility is unimportant for lasting success
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked’s exaltation is temporary and leads to ruin
questions.explanation: Job 20:6-7 teaches that though the wicked’s head may reach the clouds, they shall perish forever, urging believers to pursue humility and lasting contentment.

questions.question: Based on Job 20, how should a believer respond when witnessing others who oppress the poor or take what is not theirs?
options: Trust that God will bring justice and judgment
Assume they will prosper without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will bring justice and judgment
questions.explanation: Job 20:19-22 reveals that oppressing the poor leads to unrest and divine wrath, teaching believers to trust God’s righteous judgment.

questions.question: What lesson about spiritual discipline and personal devotion can be drawn from Job 20’s depiction of the wicked’s internal torment?
options: Sin causes hidden spiritual pain despite outward appearances
Ignoring sin leads to spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Sin causes hidden spiritual pain despite outward appearances
questions.explanation: Job 20:13-14 shows how wickedness hidden within leads to bitterness and poison inside, emphasizing the need for confession and repentance in spiritual discipline.

questions.question: How does Job 20 teach believers about perseverance through trials by highlighting the temporary nature of wickedness?
options: The wicked’s joy is brief, so believers should trust God for lasting hope
Believers should seek to imitate the wicked’s success
Temporary suffering means God has abandoned the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked’s joy is brief, so believers should trust God for lasting hope
questions.explanation: Job 20:5-8 describes the fleeting joy of the wicked and their eventual downfall, encouraging believers to persevere and trust God’s justice.

hard.title: Job Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 20.

questions.question: According to Zophar in Job 20, what is the duration of the triumphing of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: It is short
questions.explanation: Job 20:5 states 'That the triumphing of the wicked is short, and the joy of the hypocrite but for a moment,' indicating the brevity of the wicked's success.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Job 20:6-9 to describe the fate of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile and metaphor
questions.explanation: Verses 6-9 use similes and metaphors such as 'he shall perish for ever like his own dung' and 'fly away as a dream' to depict the fleeting nature of the wicked's existence.

questions.question: In Job 20, what does Zophar say about the wicked man's children in relation to the poor?
options: His children shall seek to please the poor
His children shall inherit his wealth
His children shall prosper without care
His children shall be judges of the poor
questions.correctAnswer: His children shall seek to please the poor
questions.explanation: Job 20:10 indicates that the wicked man's children will seek to please the poor, suggesting a reversal of fortunes and restitution.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'his bones are full of the sin of his youth' in Job 20:11 imply about the wicked's life?
options: Past sins remain with him until death
He is innocent of past sins
questions.correctAnswer: Past sins remain with him until death
questions.explanation: Job 20:11 metaphorically expresses that the wicked carry the burden of youthful sins throughout life, even unto death.

questions.question: What does Job 20:14 mean by 'Yet his meat in his bowels is turned, it is the gall of asps within him'?
options: The wicked experience internal bitterness and pain
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked experience internal bitterness and pain
questions.explanation: The verse uses the image of 'gall of asps' to symbolize the poisonous and bitter consequences of wickedness inside the person.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern concept is reflected in the idea that the wicked shall 'restore their goods' to the poor as in Job 20:10 and 20:18?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine justice requiring restitution
questions.explanation: The restitution theme echoes ancient laws and ethics, such as those in the Code of Hammurabi, where unjustly acquired goods are returned under divine or societal mandate.

questions.question: In Job 20:15, what is the significance of the wicked man swallowing riches and then vomiting them up again?
options: It symbolizes the futility and rejection of ill-gotten gains
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the futility and rejection of ill-gotten gains
questions.explanation: Verse 15 conveys that wealth gained by wickedness will be rejected by God, demonstrating divine judgment and the temporary nature of such riches.

questions.question: What is the Hebrew word for 'hypocrite' implied in Job 20:5, and what is its significance in the biblical context?
questions.correctAnswer: צבוע (tzavua), meaning 'painted' or 'two-faced'
questions.explanation: The Hebrew term for hypocrite often relates to 'צבוע' which metaphorically describes someone who is deceitful or insincere, consistent with the portrayal in Job 20:5.

questions.question: How does Job 20:23-25 foreshadow the themes of divine wrath and judgment found in later prophetic books like Isaiah?
options: By depicting God's wrath as a consuming weapon striking the wicked
By focusing on human justice alone
questions.correctAnswer: By depicting God's wrath as a consuming weapon striking the wicked
questions.explanation: These verses describe God's wrath raining down and the sword coming out of the wicked’s body, imagery echoed in Isaiah's prophetic denunciations of judgment.

questions.question: What is the significance of the imagery of darkness and fire not blown consuming the wicked found in Job 20:26?
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes inevitable divine punishment
questions.explanation: The 'fire not blown' suggests a divine fire consuming without human intervention, signifying certain judgment upon the wicked.

questions.question: What does Zophar mean by 'The heaven shall reveal his iniquity; and the earth shall rise up against him' in Job 20:27?
options: All creation will testify against the wicked at judgment
His sins will be hidden forever
Heaven and earth will bless him
questions.correctAnswer: All creation will testify against the wicked at judgment
questions.explanation: This verse uses cosmic imagery to express that the wicked’s sins will be exposed universally, a theme echoed in Psalms and prophetic literature.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 20, the wicked will ultimately enjoy the increase of his house and rejoice in his goods.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 20:18 and 20:28 explicitly state the wicked will restore what he laboured for and will not rejoice in it; his goods will flow away in the day of wrath.

questions.question: According to Job 20, what is the 'portion of a wicked man from God' as summarized in verse 29?
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment and destruction
questions.explanation: Verse 29 states, 'This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the heritage appointed unto him by God,' indicating divine punishment rather than blessing.

questions.question: How does the theme of fleeting wickedness in Job 20 parallel the New Testament teaching in James 4:14 about life being a vapor?
options: Both emphasize the transient nature of worldly success and life
Both emphasize eternal rewards for the wicked
Both teach that wickedness leads to prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize the transient nature of worldly success and life
questions.explanation: Job 20:8 describes the wicked flying away as a dream, similar to James 4:14's metaphor of life as a vapor, underscoring the brevity of human existence and success.

questions.question: What cultural context from the ancient Near East does the depiction of 'the bow of steel' and 'the glittering sword' in Job 20:24-25 reflect?
options: Common martial imagery signifying warfare and divine judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Common martial imagery signifying warfare and divine judgment
questions.explanation: The references to iron weapons and swords reflect the militaristic culture of the ancient Near East, used here figuratively to represent divine punishment.

theological.title: Job Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Zophar in Job 20, what is the nature of the triumph of the wicked?
options: The triumph of the wicked is short and fleeting
The triumph of the wicked lasts forever
The triumph of the wicked brings eternal joy
The triumph of the wicked is hidden from all
questions.correctAnswer: The triumph of the wicked is short and fleeting
questions.explanation: Job 20:5 states that the triumphing of the wicked is short, and the joy of the hypocrite but for a moment, emphasizing the temporary nature of wicked success. This aligns with Psalm 37:10, Proverbs 10:27, Ecclesiastes 8:13, and Luke 6:24 which all highlight the fleeting nature of wicked prosperity.

questions.question: What does Zophar say happens to the wicked man’s riches according to Job 20?
options: He swallows them down but will vomit them up again
He keeps them forever as a blessing
He shares them generously with the poor
They multiply and bring lasting joy
questions.correctAnswer: He swallows them down but will vomit them up again
questions.explanation: Job 20:15 says the wicked swallows riches but will vomit them up, showing that ill-gotten wealth is ultimately lost. This theme is echoed in Proverbs 13:11, Ecclesiastes 5:10, Luke 12:15, and 1 Timothy 6:9 about the fleeting and harmful nature of riches gained unrighteously.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The eye also which saw him shall see him no more; neither shall his ______ any more behold him.'
questions.correctAnswer: place
questions.explanation: Job 20:9 states that the eye which saw the wicked man shall see him no more, and his place shall no more behold him, indicating complete removal and loss of position. This is consistent with Psalm 37:10, Isaiah 57:1, Proverbs 10:7, and Matthew 24:28 about the disappearance of the wicked.

questions.question: What does Job 20 say about the sin of the wicked man’s youth?
options: His bones are full of the sin of his youth
His sins are forgiven and forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: His bones are full of the sin of his youth
questions.explanation: Job 20:11 states that the wicked’s bones are full of the sin of his youth, illustrating that sin has long-lasting consequences. Similarly, Psalm 51:5, Ecclesiastes 7:20, Romans 3:23, and Hebrews 12:1 emphasize the pervasive and enduring nature of sin.

questions.question: According to Job 20, what happens to the wicked man's peace and satisfaction?
options: He shall not feel quietness in his belly
He shall find peace in his wealth
He shall be satisfied with his desires
He shall enjoy rest and comfort
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not feel quietness in his belly
questions.explanation: Job 20:20 says the wicked will not feel quietness or satisfaction, a consequence of their sin and oppression. This is consistent with Isaiah 57:20-21, Jeremiah 6:14, Matthew 11:28-30, and Psalm 55:22 which contrast peace with the unrest of the wicked.

questions.question: What does Job 20 declare about the destiny of the wicked’s house and goods?
options: The increase of his house shall depart, and his goods shall flow away
They shall be preserved and multiply
They shall be inherited by his children in peace
They shall be hidden and protected
questions.correctAnswer: The increase of his house shall depart, and his goods shall flow away
questions.explanation: Job 20:28 reveals that the wicked’s possessions will disappear in the day of wrath, signifying divine judgment. This matches the teaching in Proverbs 11:4, Psalm 73:18, Matthew 6:19-20, and James 5:1-3 about the transitory nature of worldly wealth for the wicked.

questions.question: What imagery is used in Job 20 to describe the internal consequences of wickedness?
options: His meat in his bowels is turned to gall of asps
His heart is filled with joy and peace
His mind is clear and focused
His body is healed and strong
questions.correctAnswer: His meat in his bowels is turned to gall of asps
questions.explanation: Job 20:14 uses the metaphor of gall in the bowels to illustrate the bitterness and poison of sin within a person. This aligns with Jeremiah 9:15, Romans 3:13, Proverbs 14:34, and Hebrews 12:15 which show sin’s damaging internal effects.

questions.question: What does Job 20 say about God’s role in the punishment of the wicked?
options: God shall cast the fury of his wrath upon him
questions.correctAnswer: God shall cast the fury of his wrath upon him
questions.explanation: Job 20:23 states that God will pour out His wrath on the wicked, showing divine justice. This is consistent with Nahum 1:2, Romans 1:18, Revelation 6:16-17, and Psalm 7:11 which affirm God’s righteous judgment against sin.

questions.question: How does Job 20 describe the visibility of the wicked’s fate to others?
options: The heaven shall reveal his iniquity; and the earth shall rise up against him
His sins will remain hidden from all
Only a few will notice his downfall
His fate will be secret and unnoticed
questions.correctAnswer: The heaven shall reveal his iniquity; and the earth shall rise up against him
questions.explanation: Job 20:27 proclaims that God will expose the wicked’s sin openly, showing universal accountability. This corresponds with Luke 8:17, Romans 2:16, 1 Corinthians 4:5, and Matthew 10:26 on the revelation of hidden deeds.

questions.question: What does Job 20 say about the wicked man’s relationship to the poor?
options: He has oppressed and forsaken the poor
He has cared for and helped the poor
He has ignored the poor but not oppressed them
He has sought to please the poor
questions.correctAnswer: He has oppressed and forsaken the poor
questions.explanation: Job 20:19 says the wicked oppresses and forsakes the poor, a cause for divine judgment. This teaching is echoed in Proverbs 22:22-23, Isaiah 1:17, James 1:27, and Luke 4:18 about God’s concern for the oppressed and poor.

questions.question: According to Job 20, what is the ultimate portion or heritage of the wicked man from God?
options: This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the heritage appointed unto him
They receive blessings and long life
They inherit the land and peace
questions.correctAnswer: This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the heritage appointed unto him
questions.explanation: Job 20:29 declares that the fate of the wicked is their appointed portion from God, emphasizing divine justice. This aligns with Psalm 1:6, Proverbs 11:31, Romans 6:23, and Hebrews 10:31 on the consequences of wickedness.

questions.question: What does Job 20 indicate about the wicked man’s children and their need to restore goods?
options: His children shall seek to please the poor, and his hands shall restore their goods
His children will inherit wealth without trouble
His children will be blessed and prosperous
His children will ignore the poor and take more
questions.correctAnswer: His children shall seek to please the poor, and his hands shall restore their goods
questions.explanation: Job 20:10 shows that the wicked’s children will have to make restitution, reflecting the lasting effects of sin. This is consistent with Exodus 22:1, Proverbs 22:22, Ezekiel 18:4, and 2 Corinthians 5:10 regarding accountability for one’s deeds.

questions.question: How does Job 20 describe the wicked man’s fate in relation to weapons?
options: He shall flee from the iron weapon, and the bow of steel shall strike him through
He shall be protected from all weapons
He shall conquer his enemies with weapons
He shall hide from weaponry in safety
questions.correctAnswer: He shall flee from the iron weapon, and the bow of steel shall strike him through
questions.explanation: Job 20:24 depicts the wicked man as unable to escape violent judgment, symbolized by weapons. This fits with Psalm 37:14-15, Isaiah 54:17, Revelation 19:15, and Proverbs 21:31 about God's sovereign judgment and protection of the righteous.

questions.question: What does Job 20 say about the wicked man’s end compared to his own dung?
options: He shall perish for ever like his own dung
He shall be exalted like dung turned into gold
He shall be cleansed and renewed
questions.correctAnswer: He shall perish for ever like his own dung
questions.explanation: Job 20:7 uses the metaphor of dung to illustrate the utter degradation and final perishability of the wicked. This metaphor is supported by Psalm 73:18, Isaiah 40:17, Jeremiah 17:4, and Luke 16:19-31 about the final judgment and loss of the wicked.

questions.question: According to Job 20, what is the wicked man’s experience with sweetness and hiding of wickedness?
options: Though wickedness be sweet in his mouth, yet it becomes poison within
Wickedness tastes bitter and is rejected
Wickedness is openly confessed and repented
Wickedness leads to joy and peace
questions.correctAnswer: Though wickedness be sweet in his mouth, yet it becomes poison within
questions.explanation: Job 20:12-14 presents the paradox that wickedness may seem sweet but turns bitter and poisonous internally, showing sin’s deceptive nature. This is consistent with Proverbs 5:3-4, Hebrews 3:13, James 1:14-15, and Romans 7:15 about the allure and danger of sin.
